Comment: I'm sort of disappointed that they changed Hugh and Fiona's ages. They were so much older in the books, and now seeing them so young in the movies it makes me uncomfortable. Everyone's complaining about how they switched Olive and Emma's peculiarities, but I understand the reason they had to. There is so many more things they can do with Emma's new peculiarity. Olive's age disappoints me to, she was so young in the books and now grew to be older in the movie. Bronwyn's age changed also, having her been older in the books. Though they absolutely nailed the wights and hollowgast they put in this movie, along with Miss Peregrine. Even though it's not exactly like the book, It is my favorite movie and will most likely will be that way forever.

And at the end, the boy failed to protect the children, resulting at the end of all their lives. Then, miss peregrine came back with the bodies of the children lyinh before her. They died but she continies to live.
Over the years, she abadoned taking care of the house and the nature took over it, tranforming it along with the rest of thr land into a one uncared forest. Miss peregrine herself transformed too. What was once a beautiful wing of her bird form changed into one black, giant pair of wings behind her. She grew horns and her behaviour changed. What was once a caring mother transformed onto an evil witch with an intention of harm deeply rooted on a blackish heart. She was known as "Maleficent".

Title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
PLEASE READ THIS IF YOU WANT A SEQUEL. SCROLL DOWN TO LAST PARAGRAPH FOR MAIN POINT

Hi guys, I loved this movie sooo much and have been praying for a sequel ever since I watched it in 2016. You won't believe me, for the past 2 years every single week I would check for any news hoping desperately for a sequel. It was rated decently on IMBD and definitely had a nice box office turnout, so the financial assurance is there. I just wanted to say straight away, I'm quite annoyed at the very least of the people complaining about how the movie is bad because it's not like the books, NOT EVERY MOVIE HAS  TO EXACTLY MIRROR THE BOOK. For God's sake...it's called an "adaptation" for a reason and I love it. 

The opportunity is clearly there, although I can't remember the books exaclty I think they can make a sequel based on the original book trilogy, following with 'Hollow City', or definitely the new trilogy "Map of days" - based on the blurb it seems to be a perfect sequel to the events of the movie and thus can easily be adapted.

Down to the point. I have prepared a petition to directly mail Mr Tim Burton himself, I just need the confidence that this community we have that is crying for a sequel still exists. Please LIKE to indicate your support to the petition. Hopefully we reach atleast 50 likes in ~2 months. I know it sounds a lot but if you're reading this, all it takes is just 1 tap and you could make the difference to making our dreams come true. It would be great also if you could possibly just COMMENT your socials email or anything so that I can contact you for the petition when we reach our target. I truly believe we can bring Tim Burton's attention back to this movie, but honestly need your support more than ever.

Comment:
The most wonderful experience I've ever had.

Miss peregrine's home for peculiar children reminds me of the youth home I was sent to when I was 14. It was once an orphanage that housed many children in the late 1800's. The experience was both haunting and breathtaking. One of the counselors took us to the cemetery to see a few of the graves of the children who had died where I was staying. The only mansion I would ever consider as one of the great's because of it's history. If I was to ever have a dream, it would be to remain a spirit there after I die.

I will give the name and location but it is not a place to randomly visit if you didn't live there as it is not open to the general public.

The good will farm in Houghton Michigan. 

Some of my Best memories were spent living there, the third floor along with the basement was creepy just in general, so I hated laundry day and would run up quickly from the basement when done. The counselors were nice and took us on many outdoor activities. It was one of the most gothic feeling experiences I ever had.

Comment: I just saw it after listening to the audiobook (which I loved, by the way) and I must say: this has been the worst disappointment of my life. It's like they literally just read two thirds (or maybe half) of the book, threw it aside and decided to write the rest by themselves. It's an awful, awful mess. It starts off good, a bit rushed but it's still fine, then it starts to make up its own rules and its own plot. Still okay though, I can manage with an adaptation. But then it just goes nuts. Like really, really nuts. There were a part in which I literally started laughing so much I cried buckets (I also cried because I was SO disappointed, tbh). Awful, awful, awful, and such a waste on such a great plot, visions and actors. Shame!!

Comment: Miss Peregrine's Home For Peculiar Children: from Tim Burton the director of Alice In Wonderland, Edward Scissorhands and Charlie And The Chocolate Factory. I changed it, don't judge. Because when Edward Scissorhands was released on "December 6, 1990", when Charlie and the Chocolate Factory was released on "July 10, 2005" but for Alice In Wonderland it was released on the first "February 25, 2010" and the sequel "May 26, 2016" lucky before Miss Peregrine got released on "September 27, 2016" after Alice Through The Looking Glass. So that's why Alice In Wonderland got 2 movies from 2010 and 2016 it goes in the first place, Edward Scissorhands got a movie from 1990 it goes in the second place, but Charlie And The Chocolate Factory got a movie from 2005 it goes in the third place. Just like the trailer called Oz The Great And Powerful the right words belong in order both movies, like this: 1) Oz The Great And Powerful: from the visionary director of The Spider-Man Trilogy and the producer of Alice In Wonderland and 2) Miss Peregrine's Home For Peculiar Children: from the director of Alice In Wonderland, Edward Scissorhands and Charlie And The Chocolate Factory. But they put it on disorder and unorganized, like this: 1) Oz The Great And Powerful: from the producer of Alice In Wonderland and the visionary director of The Spider-Man Trilogy and 2) Miss Peregrine's Home For Peculiar Children: from the director of Edward Scissorhands, Charlie And The Chocolate Factory and Alice In Wonderland.

Comment:
The movie was amazing.  I would even say so comparing it to the book.  Granted, there are *so* many differences, but in my personal opinion both the book and the movie are incredibly well done.  Perhaps the movie didn't follow the book exactly, but I think the details added and taken away also made up for a really good piece of entertainment!  They were both so well done, it's so hard to choose which one is better.  Then again, I'm not sure I'd really want to.  Having them both be so wonderful on their on is perfectly okay with me.  Though, to anyone who's read the books and hasn't seen the movie, or vise versa, I highly recommend you watch the movie/read the books.  The differences aren't quite appealing at first, but you'll (most likely) get used to them, and I think knowing the story from both sides is very fun, so in my opinion you should give it a shot. ^^
((Then again, if it's not for you, or you don't like movies and/or books, that's fine too ^^))

Comment: I'm debating on even going to see this movie. After reading all 3 of the books, this trailer is NOT in the slightest bit accurate. Emma's peculiar ability is fire, they switched Emma and Olive's ability. Which is a big deal considering Emma is this fiery, aggressive teen, while olive is this sweet, bubbly child. Bronowyn is NOT a child, she's a teen. Horace doesn't have a projector in his eye, Hugh is also a teen, not a child, thus his love for Fiona. And forgive me if I'm wrong, but at which moment does Ms. Peregrine leave the children in Jacob's care? forgive me if I'm reading too much into this, but it isn't at all like the book. Also: Hollows are supposed to be slimy BLACK oval like creatures with several tongues, and not at all resembling a human figure. Why does the hollow at the end look like slenderman?

Title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
So... Fox... serious talk... are you doing this because you cut a deal with Marvel to bring the mutants back to the MCU?  I mean, why else would you do something that's literally just X-Men but with some Tim Burton-y twist to it?

I mean, I guess it's a fair trade-off to get the X-Men and Deadpool in the MCU, but still... come on guys... this is OBVIOUSLY just X-Men... and looking at the comment section, I'm not the ONLY one who's noticed it's just X-Men.  Is this where Young Adult novels are going now?  Instead of ripping off Twilight and Hunger Games, we've moved on to ripping off comic books now?  Are we going to get a man-made peculiarity from some kind of potion that gives people enhanced conditioning?  Is there going to be some magic wave of energy that turns people into giant hulking green beasts?  Are we going to see Gods come down and mingle with humans?  How about somebody with a special suit of armor that causes them to fly and fire weapons?  What about a rival group of people from a school called Mr. Bald's Dormitory for Unusual Youths?  Will we see these kids go into space and encounter a talking squirrel and his cactus sidekick?

Title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
Here are the inconsistencies from the book, from what I can see:
1: The Home is underwater, which did not happen in the book. 
2: Olive did not introduce him to the Home, he chased Emma there.
3: Bronwyn was around 13 if I am not mistaken, not 8.
4: Olive does not have the ability to fill underwater areas with air. She also was about 6 or 7, and wore a headpiece. Her power stemmed from being lighter than air, so she had to be anchored with leaden shoes, which were shown.
- All of this aside, I think the cast looks pretty good, especially Claire and Jake. Miss Peregrine could've been portrayed by someone a bit older, but the movie should be interesting. The special effects look excellent and I feel that Tim Burton and his darker style were perfect for directing this movie. Please note that this is only my opinion, and you are allowed to have your own.

Title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: My mom bought the book for me becuase the movies was coming out. At first the book didnt look interesting. 15 minutes later, I could feel the book pulling me forth to read it, like there was some unknown forse that knew I had to read it. It would talk me two weeks to read a book about that thick. It took my 4 days, less than a week. It was the greatest book I had ever read!!! Later in the year I went on a trip, and we were in this little town with a book store. I was looking at this pretty interesting book when my mom said, "Hey, here's the secound book to Mrs. Peregrines Home For Puculair Children." I dropped the book I was holding, and held it in my arms. I am currently reading it. I looked up the trailor, more exited than any OTHER trailer. I start watching. Me: Bronwyn isn't a little girl... Olive IS a little girl... Fionia is older... Huge dosen't have a bee net over his head... AND THE MOST ANNOYING ONE... OLIVE AND EMMA SWITHCHED PLACES!!!?????? The directors couldn't have messed up any more. SUCH a great book, such a dissapointing movie! NO NO NO!! The movie will get major downvotes becuase of this... How could the author let them do this?? This movie will dissapoint, and anger the hundreds of people (Like me) who LOVED the book! They couldn't have messed up any more, could they.

Title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: At first I was excited about this movie, but then I saw this trailer and realized that some things are wrong. Bronwyn isn't a toddler. She's an extremely strong, and caring young lady, who was, as I always thought of her, at least, taller than Jacob, and not as merry as she seems here. What about her brother, from the first book? And what about Olive? it seems as though Emma now has her ability, plus a few more. Peculiar children are limited to one power, not multiple. Emma is not a soft, gentle, blond, fairy like girl when she is first seen. She is fiery, literally, and frightening. And they didn't go into a sunken boat in the ocean. I'm sure I won't hate this movie, but I'm already disappointed.

Comment: I can't tell whether I love it or hate it to be honest. It's so visually appealing but also so cringey when compared to the amazing book. And what people who haven't read the book need to understand is that the children are born PECULIAR not with super powers. I think the trailer does a terrible job explaining that. Their abilities are usually pretty useless in a fight, that's why they have to hide from the monsters that are hunting them. They used to hide in plain sight by performing in freak shows. The reason the boy has to protect them is because his peculiarity is that he can see the monsters. To everyone else they are invisible.

Comment:
I have been waiting for this series to be turned into a movie since the first novel came out. If you have not read them, you definitely should - they are a fantastic series based on a completely unique and novel source for inspiration and story development. The books are an effortless read, and are relatively short (compared with so many of today's monstrous offerings).

Tim Burton is the perfect director for this movie/series, and Eva Green was an inspired choice for Miss Peregrine.

I also like the visualization of the Wights and Hollowgasts :)

Comment:
tbh, this trailer is amazing!- what i said 2 weeks ago
super exited, i decided to read the books, you know , 'cause the universe seemed super awesome
so i read the first book (in 4 days, even tho i had no time what's so ever)
and now, i rewatch this and i'm like..... what happenned...?
first of all, emma, her power was cool, didn't need to change with olive's
and her, my god, she was one of my favorite character, always so cute and optimistic....
then,they changed thing quite a bit, fiona, her character was my total favorite, with the kind of dreads, the dress and, she was the oldest you know! now, she's a 8 years old who grows plants, and hugh seems to be the same age, no couple ....
they added the ballerinas, but , to be honest, i love them xD so creepy
they changed miss peregrine's age, but she looks more badass!
the hollowgast... not at all how i immagined them.
but, all and all, i'm still exited to see that movie, but, they shouldn't call it miss peregrine, because, in my opinion, it's not quite that =/ (still love tim burton tho :) )

Title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
:( I'm a little disappointed in this trailer. I suppose they have it setup like an x-men trailer to boost interest but it seems to be confusing people into thinking it is something like x-men. It's not supposed to be. They're not mutants with 'powers' that want to save the world from other mutants. They're just kids with oddities that exist and are hiding. I really hope Emma's fire character is in the films, she was the coolest character. I normally Love Tim Burton, but this film like his last two, looks a bit too campy and Disney. sorry.
Maybe if they started the trailer like the beginning of the book where his grandfather is telling him about the children and he's exploring the old version of the house it would be a bit more unique and pull people in. Then get into the children's peculiarities and the wights. That would be a better intro and explain it in a not so xmen way. I first read the book because it looked so dark and was well written. This trailer makes the film look so mainstream.
I like the casting though. I'm sure the studio knows what they are doing and have multicultural'd it up where possible.

Title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: So many things I'm disappointed about with this adaptation. I just read all 3 books and absolutely adored them. As I read it I imagined this dystopian world with bleak dull surroundings and only colourful traits were the children's abilities. But there's so much colour in this I was shocked especially coming from Tim burton. He turned an otherwise creepy story with unsettling vintage photographs into a joke. The book had so much potential to become a horror based adult drama.Then I was disappointed at miss peregrines character. I love Eva green in penny dreadful don't get me wrong but expected miss peregrine to be older and more strict given away by the photographs. Same goes for brownyn and millard. As for Emma I'm so annoyed they gave her olives power as that would only mean there will be a drastic change in plot. I'd give it to asa butter field to being Jacob as he seems to fit my manifestation of Jacob in my mind from the books, plus he was great in the boy in striped pyjamas. The Hollows features look reasonably accurate but the reality of it was  let down by the comical cgi. Completely killed the thrill factor for me but its 2016 so any hopes of costume or animatronics has been thrown out the window. All in all, not impressed but seems as I can't make judgement from a 2 minute trailer I will watch the film and maybe it will grow on me. It looks good for a children's film but I just expected more coming from fantastic books. Eh.

3 Book Series Review...
"Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children"
If you are going to read this book, or want to read it before the movie comes out, I highly suggest you read all 3 books in the series. It is more along the lines of one giant book cut into 3. I enjoyed the 3rd book the most and truly wish they would have delved deeper into Devils Acre. I also enjoyed the Capitalist character Sharon who ran his boat tours to Devils Acre.
I don't want to give any spoilers, but I (given my politics) do not really enjoy how the ymbrynes run the show. If they do create more to the series, I hope they truly tap into this. I did not really like it that you had to somewhat wait till the 3rd book to really start to get meat on the bones of the back ground story setting and what not. I also did not like that the antagonist all used weapons, but the protagonist group were just stupid when it comes to any type of weapon. The books definitely have a liberal slant, and I was often rooting for the antagonist group.
They were good reads. If you enjoy super hero, super power, school settings, children in danger, type settings you will enjoy these books.
Hope this review helped you.
Have Fun in Life!

I used to be in the same boat as you, always "hating" movies because they didn't follow the books exactly, but these changes may have had to been made so that the movie worked well. Remember that this movie cannot be told in first person.

Title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
Ok, so out of 13 characters, only Jacob, Claire, Horace and both ymbrynes are unchanged. 
1.- According to this trailer and IMDB's casting page, Emma and Olive have changed peculiarities, also making Olive WAY older. 
2.- Millard, Fiona and Hugh are much younger, they're supposed to be in Jacob's and Emma's (physical) age range. 
3.- Bronwyn is also way younger.
4.- Enoch is portrayed as old or older than Jacob.

I can live with 2, 3 and 4, since honestly, age doesn't make that much of a difference, however, why would you butcher and then piece together as you wish the characters of Emma and Olive? Emma's peculiarity is on the verge of being a superpower, central to the character, her name, and her history with Abe Portman. Olive on the other hand, is a human helium balloon, she's not an airbender. 

I will see the movie, I am sure I will like it, I mean, the world just looks fascinating and strangely marvelous, Tim Burton's a good director and Jane Goldman a good writer, but how could they possibly believe it would be a good idea to change a mutate a core character and sort of merge it with another? I know novels are almost never translated exactly as they are to the silver screen, but things that change can be settings, ages, etc; maybe even actions, but not characters central to the story. 
I love the novels, they're wonderful, so I do sincerely hope the movie holds up against them, since with only the change mentioned in point number 1 is enough to make it a ''What if?'' regarding the original story of the novel

Comment:
I'm thankful that there's a movie coming out but come on, it's Percy Jackson all over again! If you don't want to disappoint the book readers while making a movie, then please at least make it mostly the same. 
This is something that is not a big deal: changing Jacob's name to jake
This is something that IS a big deal:
Replacing Emma with Olive (or her powers if her name is still Emma in the movie). This is because in a way Emma's fire powers had an impact on how we portrayed her personality. Emma wasn't very graceful like olive the levitating girl, she was feisty! It just really changes a lot.

Comment: Ok, so on first reader account, they have got the romance between Jacob and a peculiar child wrong; his love is NOT OLIVE! Olive is the child who can float, or use the power of levitation, not blow air out of the ship underwater, and another thing, JACOB AND EMMA ARE "BOYFRIEND AND GIRLFRIEND", not Olive! Brownie is a boyish looking girl, not the adorable girl in the video, plus, the twin boys are not read about in the book, if I recall correctly, and finally, I am going to see this just because I'm on Book Three of Three in this series, so AS BEING THE FAN GIRL I AM< I MUST TELL YOU I AM SOOOOO EXCITED FOR THE MOVIE! (BTW, hollows are invisible to everyone except Jacob, hence his powers, and hollow's tongues are black, not pink, and they have eight of them I think!) <3 <3 <3

Title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: I really don't understand all the fuss.  Yeah, Emma and Olive have swapped peculiarities and that will no doubt change much of the plot to come.  Yeah, the trailer, for the most part, looks lighthearted, not matching the tone of the book at all.  Yeah, some of the ages of the characters have been changed.  And, yeah, Tim Burton has definitely taken some liberties the readers are having trouble accepting.  Here's the thing, though: the author liked it, and fully condoned all changes made, from peculiarity swaps to age changes.  There's no way that was done for no reason at all.  This makes me believe there's a plot twist or the like that will be exclusive to the movie that they both set up together.  I also happen to think the actress shown to play Miss Peregrine will do a great job.  Besides that, I doubt it is going to be very lighthearted.  I just saw a kid holding a crossbow to a Slenderman/tentacle monster hybrid brought forth from the hottest pits of Hell, also known as a hollowghast.  I'm sorry, but that scene looked badass.  Unless that's the cliffhanger of the movie, I'm pretty sure there's a lot we're not seeing.  I'm just going to assume the most thrilling scenes are being saved for the movie.  So, c'mon people.  Let's try being positive.  "Dark Shadows" aside, Tim Burton has a pretty decent track record with things like this.  Remember "Big Fish"?  He can pull this off, he's not complete Hollywood trash yet.  Have a little faith and give it a chance.

Title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
I'm... disappointed? The book painted a really dark image in my head with colors like in Sweeney Todd and atmospheres like in Alice in Wonderland. But this seems too much like Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. Too campy compared with the source material.

I'm talking about the cinematography and the characters. This was based on a YA book but it feels like it's been toned down for younger audiences. I think that's why. I think they're trying to attract little kids and parents.

Oh well. I'm still gonna watch it just because. And I think it would feel like seeing a new story because so many things are different from the book. I hope it's as refreshing as they make it appear to be. I really really wish it was darker though. Tim has not been as dark as he used to be lately.

Title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment:
Just a friendly reminder that directors don't make the trailers, the marketing people do. Marketing people want to make a film look appealing to a wide audience and so they edit together little clips into what is basically a sales pitch. Trailers aren't supposed to capture the tone or the 'spirit' of the actual film, they're supposed to get as many bums on seats as possible.
The marketers have probably assumed that fans of the book will go see the film no matter what, and so instead they're trying to get the general public interested with dramatic music, simple gags, cool powers and cliffhangers.
Of course, the movie might turn out to be mediocre, or even not good. It might be a fairly loose adaptation of the book, but a good film in and of itself. That all remains to be seen. What I guess I'm trying to say is, it's a bit early to cry 'THIS MOVIE LOOKS SOGGY AND BAD' or 'BURTON BUNGLED IT'. It's a bit early to cry anything at all.

Comment:
Although I am excited for this movie, I can already see major differences from the book, which concerns me as I love love love the book series. 
-Emma's only power should be fire, not air? also what about olive? it's like they combined the 2 characters 
-the loop "transfer" is supposed to be through a weird hole in the ground emerging into the loop where miss peregrine's home is
-the loop is also described more grey, eery, and "war torn" in the books. the trailer shows it as sunny and happy
-ALSO they call Jacob "Jake" when the book clearly called him Jacob! 
These are just a few things that I saw. feel free to reply with thoughts or something I made been incorrect on. :)

Comment: I've noticed a couple things. 1) they've been very faithful to the books with everything I'm seeing, except for the fact that they seem to have interchanged Emma's peculiarity with Olives(correct me if I'm wrong). 2)Although Miss P. is an older woman in the books, I think Eva Green is an amazing choice for the character. I have no problems with that. 3)The Hollowgast at the end looks great(it still could have been better, but at least they're being faithful to the book). 4)My main concern is that Burton is going to ignore the history of Jacob's grandfather with Emma which is definitely not ok because to me that was one of the most interesting facet of Emma and Jacob's friendship/relationship, and a very interesting concept for me when I was reading the books. I hope that this isn't true. Oddly enough I'm not as upset that they've interchanged Emma's power with another's as much as I thought I would be. Slightly disappointing and sort of pointless to do so, but it's overlook-able. But if the film ignores Emma and Abraham Portmans(Jacob's grandfather) past together, I will be very disappointed because I am looking forward to that the most.

Title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children | Official Trailer [HD] | 20th Century FOX
Comment: What breaks my heart the most is Emma's change. Emma has a power that is unique to the story line. Its what gets them out of some binds, especially in the later books. Her power is also an expression of her personality. I don't like being the person who says read the books, but seriously. Do yourself a favor. The books, as others have said, also have a creepy undertone. Ransom Riggs does a fabulous job of weaving in creepy black and white photos that help with the visualization. It's what appealed to me right off the bat when i picked up the first book and I thought that since Tim Burton was working on this that it would carry over the creepy vibe but it didn't, at all. There is so much brightness and color and not at all like the books described. I love Eva Green so Miss P being so young doesn't bother me as much as I mind (who i assume is) Bronwyn being so young. Bronwyn plays the role of a protector in the books and here she's a little kiddo. And lastly, that was a cheap hollowgast at the end but that's just me being picky. I'm gonna wait to see what others say before spending money to go see it. It might be one for the bootleg files.

Comment: I'm so disappointed in the trailer. Like I understand plot changes that help pacing and run time and the overall transition from book to screen, but they literally switched around all the kids peculiarities and ages, which literally makes them THEM. Their powers and even their ages (spoiler alert: well their visual ages at least ) are so in sync with their personalities in the books, and they ruined that. Emma is supposed to have fire powers, Olive is the floaty girl (she's also like 6), Bronwyn is supposed to have the super strength and they gave it to they little girl. Why!? Bronwyn is one of the best supporting  characters in the books and is also a mother figure to a lot of the kids, after Miss Peregrine. I don't know. My one hope of this being good is Asa Butterfield. We'll see.
